The signal amplification of the samples in 20∼32 ° (b). Fig 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of the PDA (a), uncalcined PDA-CsPAV (b), calcined PDA-CsPAV (c) and calcined CsPAV (d). Fig 8 Fig. 9 V 2p3/2 XPS spectra of CsPAV (a,b) and PDA-CsPAV (c,d) before and after calcination. Fig 9 Fig. 10 O 1s XPS spectra of CsPAV (a,b) and PDA-CsPAV (c,d) before and after calcination. Fig 10 Fig. 11 Effect of reaction temperature on the performance of PDA-CsPAV (a) and CsPAV (b). Fig 11 Fig. 12 Preparation reproducibility (a) and catalytic stability (b) tests of PDA-CsPAV. Polydopamine modified heteropolyacids catalyst for methacrolein oxidation: Organic ammonia functionalized and regulation of morphology Yang Li a b # Qianwen Zhu a b # Yifan Yue a b Zhaobang Zhang a b Baohe Wang a b Jing Zhu a b ⁎ Jing Ma a b ⁎ a Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China aKey Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China b Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China bCollaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. # The two authors contributed equally to this work. The oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid (MAA) catalyzed by Keggin-type phosphomolybdovanadic acid catalyst belongs to the acid-catalyzed and oxygen-catalyzed co-promoted reactions. It is a challenge to design catalysts with suitable acidity and redox properties. In this paper, a strategy using organic ammonia to modify CsH3PMo11VO40 (CsPAV) was proposed. Core-shell polymerization precursors were synthesized by using polydopamine (PDA) microspheres as modifiers and templates, and regularly arranged PDA-CsPAV bowl-shaped catalysts were obtained via one-step calcination. The morphology, structure, thermal stability, acidity and redox properties of PDA-CsPAV catalysts were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, TG-DTA, XPS, SEM, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, and the catalytic performance was evaluated by oxidation of MAL to MAA. The rich functional groups on the surface of PDA microspheres combine with H4PMo11VO40 (HPAV) through strong coordination bonds to form a catalyst film. The uniform spherical structure of PDA can adjust the dispersion and morphology of CsPAV. NH4 + was formed and rearranged with heteropoly anions during calcination, which positively regulated the acidity and redox property of the catalyst. The addition of PDA accelerated electron transfer and strengthened the self-reduction process of HPAV. Compared with CsPAV, PDA-CsPAV has more acid sites and oxidation catalytic active centers (VO2+), thus exhibiting better MAL oxidation performance and good thermal stability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phosphomolybdovanadinic acid Polydopamine Methacrolein Oxidation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Methacrylic acid (MAA) is an important chemical intermediate for the synthesis of methyl methacrylate (MMA) [1,2]. The traditional acetone cyanohydrin process uses toxic HCN and corrosive H2SO4, which is not environmentally friendly. Heteropolyacids (HPAs) is an essential and efficient catalyst for the oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid (MAA). Keggin-type HPAs have strong Brönsted acidity and reversible redox property [3,4], it can be used as a green and efficient catalyst for a wide range of reactions [5]. The most common P-Mo-V-based HPAs catalyst for MAL oxidation is H4PMo11VO40 (HPAV). However, the catalyst has some defects of small specific surface area (typically less than 10 m2·g − 1) [6], few active sites, and poor thermal stability. Dipping the counterions into HPAV is the most widely used method to solve these problems. Counterions have the opposite charge with heteropoly anions and can replace hydrogen protons in HPAV. Substitution of protons by counterions can modulate the composition and properties of HPAV [7–9]. The common counterions include Cs+/Na+/K+ [10–12], and some transition metal ions such as Cu2+ and Fe3+ [13–15], etc. The introduction of counterions can change the pore structure of HPAV, increase the specific surface area, affect the acidity and redox performance of HPAV, and improve the stability. In recent years, NH4 +modified HPAV has attracted much attention. The elimination of ammonium in the calcination process can promote electron transfer and change the redox performance of the catalyst. The heteropoly acid modified by Cs+ or Cu2+ which is introduced of NH4 + has better catalytic performance [1,16,17]. Most of the reported NH4 + sources are inorganic salts. Heteropoly anions can combine with organic units to form hybrid catalysts with improved activity [18,19]. Wang et al. [20] modified CsH3PMo11VO40 with dendritic polyamide-amine as modifier. Hydrogen bonding network and mixed amino modified ammonium ions eliminate weak acid sites and promote the migration and formation of active vanadium oxide species (VO2+). Cao et al. [21] prepared Chitin-CsH3PMo11VO40 hybrid catalyst by chitin modified CsH3PMo11VO40. The acylamino group in chitin provided ammonia source and converted to NH4 + during calcination. Uniform Ch-CsPAV microspheres with more acidic sites and better redox active sites (VO2+) were obtained. Consequently, the introduction of nitrogen-containing organic compounds with larger molecular structures into HPA can provide NH4 + groups for HPAV, which can facilitate the construction of catalyst morphology and the formation of active sites [22,23]. Polydopamine (PDA) is a fascinating material inspired by mussels byssus [24], and its surface is rich in amino, imine, phenolic hydroxyl and other functional groups [25,26]. The abundant functional groups can combine with organic and inorganic materials by covalent bond, hydrogen bond, coordination, etc. The resulting organic-inorganic hybrid compounds are unique dispersibility, high chemical activity, and can accelerate electron transfer [27–29]. Herein, it is proposed that HPAV molecules are coated on the surface of PDA microspheres to form organic core-inorganic shell polymerization precursors, and then calcined to obtain composite catalysts with specific morphology. The surface properties of the catalysts were further tuned based on the optimization of HPAV acid sites and oxidation active sites. In this work, to control the morphology and optimize the acidity and redox properties of CsPAV, bowl-shaped PDA-CsH3PMo11VO40 (PDA-CsPAV) composite catalysts were prepared by one-pot method. The fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, TG-DTA, XPS, SEM, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD, and the catalytic performance was evaluated by oxidation reaction of MAL to MAA. The preparation reproducibility and long-term catalytic performance stability of the composite catalysts were investigated. The effect of PDA on the formation mechanism of acid sites and oxidation active sites was studied. This work provides research ideas for the synthesis of HPAV catalysts with specific morphology, suitable acidity and redox properties. Experimental section Materials Molybdenum trioxide (≥99.9%), vanadium oxide (≥98%), phosphoric acid (≥85%), dopamine hydrochloride (≥98%), Arginine (≥99%) and cesium hydroxide (≥99%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Ethanol absolute (≥99.7%) were purchased from Tianjin Jiangtian Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. Catalysts preparation HPAV was first prepared for subsequent preparation of hybrid catalysts, and the preparation method of HPAV is consistent with that reported in the literature [30]. PDA was prepared by the method in the reference literature [31]. PDA-CsPAV was synthesized by one-pot method: Firstly, 0.15 g dopamine hydrochloride was dissolved in a mixture of 25 mL ethanol and 150 mL deionized water to obtain dopamine salt solution, and then 0.1 g arginine was dissolved in 50 mL deionized water to get arginine solution. Dopamine salt solution and arginine solution were mixed, stirred mechanically at 25 °C for 24 h, then centrifuged and washed with water to obtain solid particles. The solid particles were dispersed in 30 mL deionized water to obtain PDA microsphere dispersion, marked A. 7.13 g HPAV and 0.67 g CsOH·H2O were dissolved in 30 mL and 10 mL deionized water, and were labeled B and C, respectively. Then the B and C solutions were dripped into the dispersion A and stirred at 80 °C for 6 h. After that, the reaction solution was dried at 80 °C for 12 h, and the precursor of PDA-CsPAV polymerization was obtained. Finally, the PDA-CsPAV catalyst was obtained by calcining the polymerization precursor at 350 °C for 12 h. CsH3PMo11VO40 (CsPAV) contrast catalyst was synthesized according to the preparation steps described above. Characterization of catalysts Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained on a Nexus 670 infrared spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) were recorded on Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5418 Å) from 5 ° to 70 ° The microscopic morphology of the catalyst surface was analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The TG/DTA curve was obtained on a Rigaku TG-DTA8122 thermal analyzer. Samples were heated from room temperature to 600 °C at a constant heating rate of 5 °C·min−1. Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out on a BELCAT II chemisorption analyzer. About 50 mg sample was pretreated with He flow, and then was adsorbed in a mixed flow of NH3/He (5% NH3, 15 mL·min−1) at 100 °C for 60 min. Finally, the temperature was increased to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 in He flow (25 mL·min−1). The NH3-TPD curve was recorded with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were performed in a BELCAT II chemisorption analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were acquired by an ESCALAB-250Xi with monochromated Al Ka radiation. Catalytic reaction experiment The performance of catalysts for selective oxidation of MAL to MAA was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. 5 mL (about 6 g) catalysts were tableted and sieved to obtain a particle size of 20–40 mesh. The catalyst was placed in the constant temperature section of the fixed bed reactor. First, 75 mL·min−1 of N2 and 10 mL·min−1 of O2 were injected into reactor. After that, when the temperature increased to a suitable reaction temperature, MAL and H2O were pumped into the preheater and gasified and injected into the reactor together with the carrier gas. After the reaction system was stable, the product was liquefied by cyclic condensation system. The liquid phase products were mainly unreacted MAL, oxidation product MAA, and some low volatile by-products. Liquid phase products were collected and analyzed using the Agilent-6820 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped by a thermal conductivity cell detector (TCD) with a HP-INNOWAX capillary column. The highly volatile byproducts (such as: CO and CO2) were detected using an HP-PLOT packed column. The performance evaluation device of the catalyst is consistent with that reported in the literature [30], as shown in Fig. S1. Results and discussion Characterization of catalysts FT-IR (Fig. 1 ) was performed to investigate the chemical composition and the function groups of the PDA, CsPAV and PDA-CsPAV. The typical absorption bands of Keggin structure appeared in the range of 1100–700 cm−1 for PDA-CsPAV before and after calcination. The peaks at 1062 cm−1, 965 cm−1, 862 cm−1 and 773 cm−1 were assigned to P-Oi, Mo=Od, Mo-Ob-Mo and Mo-Oc-Mo, respectively [30,32,33]. The broad peak of 3500 cm−1 to 3000 cm−1 in the PDA band was attributed to the stretching vibration peaks of OH and NH, and the absorption peaks at 1615 cm−1 and 1718 cm−1 corresponded to the typical C = C and C = O vibration peaks in the quinone group, respectively [29,34]. The results show that the dopamine monomer was successfully polymerized into PDA microspheres. In addition, the infrared absorption peaks belonging to PDA can also be observed in PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursors, which means that CsPAV combined with PDA microspheres by hydrogen bonding to form PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursors [35]. Compared with CsPAV, the four Keggin structural characteristic peaks of the polymerization precursors were slightly red-shifted. There is a strong hydrogen bond and electrostatic interaction between HPAV and PDA amino ligands, which leads to the decrease of vibration frequency and tensile strength of heteropoly structures [36]. After calcination, the characteristic peak of alkyl chain of PDA-CsPAV disappeared, and new vibration peaks at 3215 cm−1 and 1415 cm−1 attributed to NH4 + appeared [37]. The results show that there was a chemical reaction between PDA microspheres and HPAV during the calcination process, and the nitrogen-containing groups on the surface of PDA were transformed into ammonium ions coordinated with heteropoly anions. In addition, the absorption bands at 1035 cm−1 and 594 cm−1 of calcined catalyst were assigned to VO2+ and MoO3 [38]. Some vanadium and molybdenum atoms in the Keggin structure of the catalyst were disconnected from the P-Oi bond and released. The reduced vanadium and molybdenum species migrated and aggregated to the secondary structure, and the defective heteropoly acid catalyst was formed. The XRD spectra of the catalysts before and after calcination are shown in Fig. 2 . All the samples show characteristic diffraction peaks of typical cubic phase (2θ = 10.4 °, 18.5 °, 23.8 °, 26.2 °, 30.1 °, 35.7 °) [3]. Compared with CsPAV (26.14 °) before calcination, the main diffraction peak of PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursor shifted to low angle (26.12 °), indicating that the crystal size of the catalyst became larger and the crystal cell was swollen. However, the main diffraction peak of PDA-CsPAV shifted obviously to the high angle (26.28 °) after calcination. According to Scheler's formula, the PDA-CsPAV catalyst has the smallest crystal cell parameters and grain size. The changes of cell parameters and grain size were attributed to the enthalpy contribution of lattice energy in the process of calcination of polymerization precursor to cesium molybdovanadate ammonium salt, that is, the interaction energy of NH4 + with heteropoly anions is higher than that of Cs+ and H+ with heteropoly anions [39]. Fig. 3 is SEM diagram of the microstructure of PDA, PDA-CsPAV and CsPAV. PDA was a uniform sphere with size of about 133 nm from Fig. 3(a). For uncalcined PDA-CsPAV, HPAV molecules were coated on the surface of PDA microspheres to form solid microspheres with rough surface from Fig. 3(b). The calcined PDA-CsPAV exhibited a regular arrangement of double-layer or three-layer bowl shaped morphology, and abundant pore structure can be observed in the particles from Fig. 3(c). The pore structure and bowl shape of the catalyst were formed by sintering and collapsing of the polymerization precursor in high temperature gas flow. On the contrary, CsPAV was irregular hardening and block morphology as shown in Fig. 3(d). Using organic compounds to modify heteropoly compounds can change the morphology of the catalyst, and the modified catalyst has more uniform structure. The uniform structure made the distribution of NH4 + more uniform and facilitated the exposure of more active centers. The same phenomenon has been reported in the literature [18,21,36]. HPAV was supported on PDA microspheres to form core-shell polymerization precursors, and then the polymerization precursors were calcined to form composite catalysts with specific morphology. In the preparation of hybrid catalysts, the rich functional groups on the surface of PDA nanospheres can play the role of structural guidance and pore formation. The synthesis scheme of PDA-CsPAV catalyst deduced from above characterization analysis is suggested as Fig. 4 . Heteropoly anions and amino ligands of PDA were anchored by hydrogen bonding and a catalyst film was formed on the surface of PDA to form precursor microspheres with organic core-inorganic shell structure. During calcination, the nitrogen-containing groups of PDA were converted into NH4 + and coordinated with heteropoly anions. NH4 +, Cs+, H+ counterions and crystalline water were rearranged in the secondary structure of heteropoly acid to achieve charge balance. The hydrocarbon chains in the polymerization precursor microspheres were broken and decomposed to form a cavity and further collapsed to form a bowl-shaped morphology. In addition, the formation of NH4 + during calcination will have accumulation effect on HPAV nanocrystals, and the voids between microcrystals created a rich pore structure of the hybrid catalyst. The structure-induced effect of PDA microspheres during calcination promoted the assembly of Keggin unit clusters into particles with a new tertiary structure, while core-shell hybrid nanospheres were transformed into ordered double-layer or three-layer bowl-shaped porous catalysts. The TG/DTA curves of PDA, uncalcined CsPAV and uncalcined PDA-CsPAV at 25–650 °C are shown in Fig. 5 . For all samples, the weight loss below 200 °C corresponded to the desorption of physically adsorbed water on the surface [5]. For uncalcined PDA-CsPAV, the weight loss in the range of 250 °C to 450 °C was attributed to the thermal decomposition of organic matter and active phase in the precursor of PDA-CsPAV polymerization. The decomposition sequence was roughly as follows: the decomposition of organic chain of PDA molecules, the loss of crystalline water, decomposition after the chemical reaction of nitrogen-containing groups and heteropoly anions to form NH4 +. The high activity defective heteropoly acid catalyst with Keggin structure was formed during the decomposition process [40]. From the thermal weight loss of PDA and PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursors during calcining, the mass fraction of CsPAV in the polymerization precursors was calculated to be 94.5 wt%. In addition, compared with the TG curve of CsPAV, the decomposition temperature of PDA-CsPAV was lower. The loss of structural water during the calcining process will accelerate the decomposition of PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursors. When the calcination temperature was 350 °C, some ammonia active groups and structural water were retained in the crystal structure of the catalyst, and the suitable catalytic performance of the catalyst can be obtained in the process of MAL oxidation. The acid center properties of the catalysts were investigated by NH3-TPD. Fig. 6 is the NH3 desorption curves of CsPAV and PDA-CsPAV catalysts. Both the two catalysts have desorption peaks in weak acid region (100–350 °C) and medium-strong acid region (350–550 °C) [41,42]. The two desorption peaks were produced by the thermal desorption of adsorbed ammonia at Lewis acid sites and Brönsted acid sites, respectively. The desorption peak in the medium-strong acid region of the PDA-CsPAV composite catalyst corresponded to the ammonia desorption at the acidic sites of Brönsted and the decomposition of NH4 + in the secondary structure. Ammonia desorption experiments were carried out on the composite catalyst without ammonia adsorption to eliminate the effect of NH4 + decomposition in the catalyst. The total acidity of Brönsted of PDA-CsPAV after correction (0.31 mmol·g − 1) was higher than that of CsPAV (0.24 mmol·g − 1). The acid catalytic activity sites of MAL to MAA catalytic oxidation system is the acid sites of Brönsted at 350–550 °C, and there were more acid sites in PDA-CsPAV than in CsPAV. Therefore, it can be inferred that the catalytic efficiency of PDA-CsPAV catalyst is higher than that of CsPAV. Compared with CsPAV, the positions of the two desorption peaks of PDA-CsPAV shifted significantly to the strong acid region, which means that the introduction of PDA significantly optimized the acid site properties of CsPAV catalysts because NH4 + was formed during calcination [21]. The H2-TPR characterization results of CsPAV and PDA-CsPAV after calcination are shown in Fig. 7 . CsPAV showed a main reduction peak at 570–650 °C, corresponding to the metal oxides (MoO3, V2O5) generated by the decomposition of heteropoly anions [43]. However, besides the main reduction peak at 540–620 °C, PDA-CsPAV had a reduction peak attributed to V5+ at about 360 °C [40]. Therefore, after calcination at 350 °C, PDA-CsPAV can produce more active VO2+. The maximum reduction temperature of PDA-CsPAV (590 °C) was significantly lower than that of CsPAV (620 °C), indicating that the introduction of PDA enhanced the redox ability of heteropoly acid catalysts. The above results show that the introduction of PDA into HPAV catalyst can accelerate the transfer rate of electrons from bulk phase to surface in heteropoly anions [44], promote the formation of redox centers and improve the redox activity of the catalyst. The valence state and composition of the near surface elements of CsPAV and PDA-CsPAV catalysts were analyzed by XPS technique. The relative quantization results of the species composition of the samples (expressed in atomic ratio) and the different chemical states of the elements (expressed in molar ratio) are shown in Table 1 . The N 1s, V 2p3/2, Mo 3d, O 1s spectra of catalysts before and after calcination are displayed in Fig. 8 , Fig. 9 , Fig. S3 and Fig. 10 , respectively. First, the composition determined by the atomic ratio is analyzed. The variability of V/P ratio (Table 1) indicates the rearrangement of element V on the surface of the catalyst. Compared with CsPAV, the ratio of V/P of PDA-CsPAV catalyst increased. The increase in the ratio was caused by the migration of V from the bulk to the surface [37]. Fig. 8 is the N 1s XPS spectra of PDA-CsPAV before and after calcination. For PDA-CsPAV catalyst before calcination, there was only one peak assigning to Mo6+ at 398.96 eV. The calcined PDA-CsPAV catalyst exhibited a new peak belonging to NH4 + (402.41 eV) in the N 1s spectra, indicating that the group evolution occurred in the polymerization precursor during the calcination process and NH4 + was formed. Besides, compared with the uncalcined PDA-CsPAV, the Mo/N atomic ratio of the calcined catalyst increased from 8.94 to 12.22 (Table 1). The decrease of the proportion of N element in the calcined catalyst is due to the release of ammonia from the Keggin structure during calcination, which is consistent with the characterization results of TG/DTA. According to the skeleton charge balance, the N species originally located in organic groups were converted to NH4 + counterions coordinated with heteropoly anions after calcination [18]. Fig. S2 is full spectra and C 1s spectra of uncalcined PDA-CsPAV. The peaks of PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursors at 399.5 eV assigned to the amino groups on PDA heterocycles. The three splitting peaks in C 1s spectra were attributed to 284.5 eV (C = C and CC), 285.7 eV (CO and CN) and 288.7 eV (C = O), respectively [29]. The existence of C = O indicates the successful formation of PDA microspheres containing quinone groups, which is consistent with the characterization results of FT-IR. Fig. S3 is the Mo 3d spectra of CsPAV and PDA-CsPAV before and after calcination. The binding energy and peak area of Mo did not change obviously before and after calcination for the two catalysts, indicating that the existence of PDA has little effect on the chemical state of Mo element. The peaks of V 2p3/2 for PDA-CsPAV and CsPAV are shown in Fig. 9. The binding energy at around 516.7 eV and 517.8 eV of the two catalysts before and after calcination corresponded to V4+ and V5+ species [30]. No other V species were detected in the range of 520–515 eV, which was consistent with the reports in the literature [17,18,37]. During the calcination process, the relative molar ratio of V4+/V5+ in the PDA-CsPAV catalyst increased from 0.52 to 1.33 (Table 1). The organic components in the polymerization precursors produced NH4 + during calcination, which promoted the reduction of V5+ to V4+. The molar ratio of V4+/V5+ in PDA-CsPAV was significantly higher than that in CsPAV (0.40) after calcination. The introduction of PDA strengthened the self-reduction process of HPAV catalyst [45]. The reasons for the increase of the proportion of V4+/V5+ after calcination are as follows: (1) during the calcination process, the bridging oxygen or terminal oxygen was easy to break and precipitate lattice oxygen (O2−) and form oxygen vacancy, more electron transfer in heteropoly anions promoted the reduction of vanadium species. (2) The oxidative decomposition of organic precursors to form NH4 +, reduced the structural stability of Keggin structure and promoted the reduction of V5+ to V4+. As the redox active center of HPAV catalyst, a large number of reduced vanadium species (VO2+) were generated and migrated to the secondary structure. VO2+ is helpful to improve the catalytic performance of heteropoly acid [38,46]. The oxygen atoms in the skeleton structure of Keggin can be divided into three types: relatively stable central oxygen Oi (P-Oi), a large number of highly active bridging oxygen OB (Mo-Ob-Mo/V, Mo-Oc-Mo/V), terminal oxygen Od (Mo/V=Od) [47]. The hydrated protons on the terminal oxygen were the acidic sites of heteropoly acids. In the process of calcination and catalysis, the lattice oxygen formed by bridging oxygen or terminal oxygen fracture was helpful to enhance the redox performance of heteropoly acid. Therefore, the content and properties of active oxygen atoms in heteropoly anions have a direct effect on the activity of the catalyst. Based on this, the binding energy and distribution of different types of oxygen species in the catalyst before and after calcination were studied [48]. O 1s XPS spectra of PDA-CsPAV before and after calcination are shown in Fig. 10(c) and Fig. 10(d). For uncalcined PDA-CsPAV, the deconvoluted spectra for O 1s exhibited three main peaks at 530.81 eV, 531.42 eV and 532.18 eV, linked to Od, OB and Oi species. The relative peak area ratio of the three O species was 0.36, 0.31 and 0.32 from Table 1. For calcined PDA-CsPAV, the three main peaks of O 1s at 530.65 eV, 531.28 eV, 531.94 eV and the relative peak area ratio was 0.54, 0.26, 0.20. O 1s XPS spectra of CsPAV before and after calcination are shown in Fig. 10(a)-Fig. 10(b), the three main peaks of O 1s at 530.72 eV, 531.22 eV, 531.93 eV and the relative peak area ratio was 0.46, 0.30, 0.24 for uncalcined CsPAV. Compared with the uncalcined CsPAV, there was almost no obvious change in the binding energy and molar ratio of oxygen species after calcined. Different from CsPAV, the three O 1s species of PDA-CsPAV catalyst changed significantly before and after calcination. The proportion of terminal oxygen Od in the uncalcined PDA-CsPAV was significantly lower than that of CsPAV. But the proportion of terminal oxygen Od in the calcined composite catalyst increased greatly. The O atoms of quinone group (C = O) and catechol group (COH) in PDA microspheres coincided with the central oxygen Oi and bridging oxygen OB of heteropoly acid to occupy a large cleavage peak area [35,49,50]. During the calcination process, the oxygen atoms originally belonging to the organic group disappeared due to the decomposition of the organic chain in PDA. Thus, the relative content of terminal oxygen Od in the composite catalyst increased from 0.36 to 0.54. In addition, the formation and migration of a large amount of VO2+ changed the redox potential around the oxygen atoms, resulting in the decrease of the binding energy of oxygen species in PDA-CsPAV after calcination. This result further verified the analytical conclusions of FT-IR and H2-TPR. Through the introduction of PDA modifier into HPAV, the ratio of V4+/V5+ and terminal oxygen (Od) in HPAV catalyst was increased, which means that PDA-CsPAV composite catalyst has stronger redox performance. Catalytic performance of the catalysts Compared with the CsPAV catalyst, the PDA-CsPAV composite catalyst exhibited rich pore structure, bowl-shaped morphology and better acidity and redox performance. The oxidation of MAL to MAA was used as a probe reaction to study the performance of the catalyst. This work was based on the previous studies and further discussion was carried out [30]. The effect of reaction temperature on the performance of the catalyst was investigated, and the long-term performance was evaluated. Effect of reaction temperature on the performance of catalyst As shown in Fig. 11 (a), for the catalyst PDA-CsPAV, with the increase of reaction temperature, the MAL conversion increased gradually, and the selectivity to MAA increased at first and then decreased. From 290 °C to 310 °C, the selectivity to MAA increased from 87.0% to 95.1%, but decreased to 73.6% at 330 °C (Fig. 11(a)). The change of selectivity was due to the over-activation of MAL and the deep oxidation of MAA at high temperature. For the contrast catalyst CsPAV, the conversion and selectivity were lower than PDA-CsPAV. Even if the temperature rose to 330 °C, the MAL conversion was less than 70% (Fig. 11(b)). According to the above evaluation results, the highest yield of PDA-CsPAV catalyst was 71.6% at 310 °C, while that of CsPAV catalyst was only 45.6% at higher temperature (320 °C). The performance of PDA-CsPAV is compared with the literatures. Wang et al. [20] studied dendritic polyamide-amine modified phosphomolybdovanadic catalyst for methacrolein to methacrylic acid. The optimal reaction temperature was 320 °C, MAL conversion was 60%, the selectivity to MAA was 97% and yield reached the maximum was 58%. Zhou et al. [51] used carbon catalyst for selective oxidation of methacrolein to methacrylic acid. Methacrolein conversion, methacrylic acid selectivity and yield were 42.8%, 70.8% and 30.3%, respectively. Kim et al. [6] immobilized H5PMo10V2O40 catalyst on nitrogen-containing mesoporous carbon and used for methacrolein oxidation. The yield was below 70%. It can be seen that the highest yield of PDA-CsPAV was higher than that reported in the literatures, and the reaction temperature was lower [6,20]. This catalytic phenomenon is consistent with the characterization results of NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, SEM and TEM. PDA microspheres were introduced into CsPAV to form a porous bowl-like structure of heteropoly acid, which significantly improved the protonation degree and redox potential of the catalyst. Therefore, the suitable catalytic temperature of PDA-CsPAV was reduced by about 10 °C compared to CsPAV. For the oxidation of MAL to MAA reaction system, lower reaction temperature can slow down the decomposition and deactivation of Keggin structure and prolong the service life of the composite catalyst. Preparation reproducibility and stability evaluation of catalysts The preparation reproducibility of PDA-CsPAV catalyst was investigated by orthogonal experiment. The specific scheme is as follows: firstly, 3 batches of PDA microspheres and 3 batches of HPAV were synthesized respectively, then 9 batches of PDA-CsPAV composite catalysts were prepared by orthogonal method, and finally the performance evaluation experiments of 9 batches of catalysts were carried out under the same catalytic conditions. The evaluation results are shown in Fig. 12 (a), and there was no obvious fluctuation in the PDA-CsPAV catalytic performance of each batch. Therefore, this kind of catalyst had good preparation reproducibility. In addition, continuous evaluation experiments on PDA-CsPAV were carried out under the same reaction conditions to explore its long-term thermal stability. As shown in Fig. 12(b), the MAL conversion and MAA selectivity of PDA-CsPAV remained stable around 75% and 95% throughout the evaluation process, indicating that the introduction of PDA microspheres would not adversely affect the stability of the catalyst. At the same time, it was further verified that the stability of heteropoly acid catalyst was mainly related to the existence of Cs+ [11]. FT-IR and XRD were used to characterize the PDA-CsPAV catalyst after long-term evaluation. Compared with the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1(a)), the characteristic peaks of Keggin structure were existed in the used catalyst. The infrared vibration peak of NH4 + at 1415 cm−1 disappeared after long-term evaluation and the new peak corresponded to the reduced molybdenum species appeared at 624 cm−1 (Fig. 13 (a)). This shows that during the long-term reaction, ammonia was decomposed and MoO3/MoO2 was formed [11,37]. The same phenomenon has been reported in the literatures [1,18,20,21]. In order to determine the effect of NH4 + with temperature changes on acidity, the catalyst PDA-CsPAV was characterized by NH3-TPD without adsorption NH3 to eliminate the effect of the decomposition of NH4 + in PDA-CsPAV on acidity. The acidity of NH4 + decomposition was only 0.003 mmol·g − 1, accounting for about 1.89%, so the decomposition of NH4 + was very small. The effect of such a small amount of degradation on the activity of PDA-CsPAV was almost negligible. As shown in Fig. 13(b), after long-term evaluation, the characteristic peaks of Keggin structure were weakened, but the catalyst still had a complete Keggin structure unit. In addition, there were diffraction peaks belonging to MoO3, MoO2 and VO2+ at 2θ=12.9 °, 23.5 °and 26.7 °, respectively. According to the oxidation mechanism of MAL to MAA [21], the formation of reduced state of Mo and V species was beneficial to accelerate the catalytic reaction. In the process of catalytic reaction, PDA-CsPAV composite catalyst was finally transformed into defective cesium molybdovanadate, molybdenum oxide and VO2+hybrid. In the long-term evaluation experiment for 136 h, the activity of the catalyst almost did not change, which indicates that the PDA-CsPAV catalyst had good stability. General discussion According to the performance evaluation of the catalyst and the previous characterization analysis, the plausible formation mechanism of composite catalyst PDA-CsPAV and the effect of the formation of NH4 + on the catalytic active sites are shown in Fig. 14 . The addition of PDA accelerated the electron transfer and strengthened the self-reduction process of HPAV. The terminal oxygen and bridging oxygen precipitated lattice oxygen to form O vacancy, and more electron transfer promoted the reduction of VOx species to VO2+. The formation of NH4 + promoted the reduction of V species and optimized the acidity of HPAV. Thus, the acid sites and oxidation active sites of PDA modified CsPAV catalysts increased. PDA-CsPAV had better catalytic performance when it was used in MAL oxidation under the influence of both acid catalysis and oxidation catalysis. Conclusion PDA microspheres were used as modifiers and templates to prepare PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursors with organic core-inorganic shell structure. Regular double-layer or three-layer bowl-shaped composite catalysts were prepared by one-step calcination. HPAV can form strong coordination bonds with rich amino and hydroxyl groups on the surface of PDA microspheres, so HPAV can covered on the surface of PDA, thus effectively inhibiting their agglomeration behavior. The oxidative decomposition of PDA-CsPAV polymerization precursor can form NH4 + on the surface of the catalyst in calcination process, which further undergoes and coordinate rearrangement with heteropoly anions, thus significantly increasing the amount of acid sites and oxygen catalytic active sites (VO2+) of the catalyst. Besides, the addition of PDA accelerated the electron transfer, strengthened the self-reduction process of HPAV and promoted the formation of redox centers. During calcination, the bridging oxygen or terminal oxygen was easy to break and precipitate lattice oxygen (O2−) and form oxygen vacancy, more electron transfer in heteropoly anions promoted the reduction of vanadium species. The reversible redox characteristics of HPAV catalysts combined with the unique electron transfer properties of PDA reduced the reduction temperature of the composite catalysts, and the stronger redox properties lead to lower catalytic reaction temperature (310 °C). Compared with the CsPAV catalyst, PDA-CsPAV catalyst exhibits better surface morphology, higher degree of protonation and redox potential, so that the PDA-CsPAV catalyst shows higher catalytic activity with the MAL conversion of 75.3% and the MAA selectivity of 95.1%. It also showed stable catalytic performance in the continuous evaluation experiment for 136 h. coredata.dc:description: The oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid (MAA) catalyzed by Keggin-type phosphomolybdovanadic acid catalyst belongs to the acid-catalyzed and oxygen-catalyzed co-promoted reactions. It is a challenge to design catalysts with suitable acidity and redox properties. In this paper, a strategy using organic ammonia to modify CsH3PMo11VO40 (CsPAV) was proposed. Core-shell polymerization precursors were synthesized by using polydopamine (PDA) microspheres as modifiers and templates, and regularly arranged PDA-CsPAV bowl-shaped catalysts were obtained via one-step calcination. The morphology, structure, thermal stability, acidity and redox properties of PDA-CsPAV catalysts were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, TG-DTA, XPS, SEM, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, and the catalytic performance was evaluated by oxidation of MAL to MAA. The rich functional groups on the surface of PDA microspheres combine with H4PMo11VO40 (HPAV) through strong coordination bonds to form a catalyst film. The uniform spherical structure of PDA can adjust the dispersion and morphology of CsPAV. NH4 + was formed and rearranged with heteropoly anions during calcination, which positively regulated the acidity and redox property of the catalyst. The addition of PDA accelerated electron transfer and strengthened the self-reduction process of HPAV. Compared with CsPAV, PDA-CsPAV has more acid sites and oxidation catalytic active centers (VO2+), thus exhibiting better MAL oxidation performance and good thermal stability.
coredata.dc:title: Polydopamine modified heteropolyacids catalyst for methacrolein oxidation: Organic ammonia functionalized and regulation of morphology
